newsitem.title: CANADA: Northern Border gas startup now seen Nov '98.
newsitem.headline: Northern Border gas startup now seen Nov '98.

text.p: A much-anticipated expansion of the Northern Border natural gas pipeline to the U.S. Midwest from Canada is now set to come on stream on November 1, 1998, a Northern Border official said on Monday.

"We expect to get the environmental approval in March 1997 (and) have the project in service on November 1, 1998," Northern Border vice-president Robert Hill told Reuters after a presentation to a pipeline conference.
The previous in-service estimate, set when the U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission preliminarily approved the expansion with a rolled-in tolling mechanism at the end of July, was mid-1998.
That was pushed back from an earlier target of the spring of 1998.

The line currently runs to Harper, Iowa from Monchy, Saskatchewan. Under the expansion proposal, it would carry 2.4 billion cubic feet per day -- an increase of 700 million cubic feet per day -- and be extended to Chicago.
Canadian gas producers, hit by a glut within the country's borders because of a scarcity of export pipeline space, have been anxiously awaiting the expansion.

Hill said the Chicago market could likely not withstand up to two billion cubic feet of new Canadian gas from both the Northern Border expansion and the proposed, producer-backed Alliance pipeline project without major price drops.
However, Canadian gas could flow east of Chicago on various pipelines and serve the U.S. Northeast and Mid-Atlantic markets, he said.

"If Alliance is constructed, there is some reason to be concerned about the Chicago market and (opposing forces) are quite right when they say that will result in greater need for access to markets east of Chicago," he said.
Northern Border is 30-percent owned by TransCanada PipeLines Ltd and 70-percent owned by Enron Corp affiliate Northern Border Partners LP. -- Reuters Calgary Bureau 403 531-1624
